;;7 月，SAG-AFTRA 演员和美国作家协会 (WGA) 作家在美国加利福尼亚州伯班克迪士尼影城外的纠察线上行走2023 年 2 月 25 日。路透社/迈克·布莱克/档案照片;
;

;双方在联合声明中表示，好莱坞制片厂和好莱坞演员罢工谈判代表将于 10 月 2 日举行会谈;声明;周三，这是几个月来的第一次此类会议。

;

;SAG-AFTRA 演员工会，好莱坞最大的工会，拥有 16 万名会员，于 7 月份举行了罢工，要求提高工资并限制在娱乐中使用人工智能 (AI)，其要求与好莱坞作家类似。

;

;作家工会达成了一项协议与电影电视制片人联盟 (AMPTP) 达成初步协议，该联盟代表华特迪士尼 ;(DIS .N);、Netflix ;(NFLX.O); 和其他工作室经过五个月的谈判失败后，周日。

;

;SAG-AFTRA 拥有众多具有不同;他们想要解决的问题;。

;

;表演者希望保护他们的图像和作品不被用生成的“数字复制品”取代人工智能而演员们正在寻求能够反映他们为流媒体带来的价值的补偿，特别是以收入分享的形式。

;

;演员的其他要求包括对选角中使用的自录试镜的限制，他们认为这是比亲自阅读的成本更高。他们还需要能够处理各种发质和肤色的发型师和化妆师，以确保所有表演者的公平。

;;2023 年 9 月 27 日，中国北京恒大住宅小区的住宅楼附近看到恒大标志。REUTERS/Florence Lo;
;

;中国恒大集团股票交易;(3333.HK) ; 在有报道称其董事长已被任命后于周四被暂停 ;受到警方监视;，因为清算风险不断增加，人们对这家现金短缺的开发商的未来越来越担忧。

;

;负债超过 3000 亿美元 - 大致相当于芬兰国内生产总值 - 恒大已成为中国房地产行业债务危机的典型代表，该行业约占经济的四分之一。

;

;恒大及其两家子公司的股票交易周四，彭博社报道其董事长 ;许家印;本月被警方带走，并在指定地点接受监控。

;

;报道称，目前尚不清楚许家印为何受到监控，路透社也无法得知立即核实消息。恒大和警方尚未回应路透社的置评请求。

;

;恒大一直在努力获得债权人批准重组其境外债务。本周，恒大表示无法;由于对其主要中国子公司的调查而发行新债;。

;

;一些分析师认为，离岸债务重组计划现在看来将陷入停滞，公司被清算的风险正在上升

;

;路透社周二报道称，恒大集团的一项重大离岸业务;如果开发商在10月底前未提交新的债务重组计划，债权人团体;正计划加入针对开发商的清算法院请愿书。;

;“在中国，没有一家开发商是大到不能倒的，因此很难想象全面救助。尽管如此，在稳定方面，政府可能会以不同的方式发挥更大的影响力。”Ng 表示。

;

;该公司股价周三在香港市场收盘下跌 19%，跌幅收窄至停牌 17 个月后，自 8 月底恢复交易以来，股价上涨了 81%。

;

;恒大最近的困境是在北京过去几周推出一系列措施（包括削减现有抵押贷款）的背景下发生的。盛宝大中华区市场策略师Redmond Wong在一份研究报告中写道，近期的监管放松可能会在一定程度上稳定全球第二大经济体的房地产市场。< /p>;

;“尽管如此，面临人口下降的二三线城市住房库存过剩仍将持续数年，”他表示。

;

;“这将导致更多有关违约、重组的头条新闻以及无力偿债的开发商的清算，给股东、债券持有人、银行以及与房地产项目相关的信托和理财产品投资者造成损失。”

; Thu, 28 Sep 2023 12:55:03 +0800 Takeaways from the second 2024 Republican presidential debatehttps://reuters.com/article/usa-election-republicans-debate-takeaway/takeaways-from-the-second-2024-republican-presidential-debate-idUSKBN30Y02Z
;;2023-09-28T04:29:40Z;
;;
;;北达科他州州长 Doug Burgum、前新泽西州州长 Chris Christie、前南卡罗来纳州州长 Nikki Haley、佛罗里达州州长 Ron DeSantis、前生物技术高管9 月，维韦克·拉马斯瓦米、美国参议员蒂姆·斯科特 (R-SC) 和美国前副总统迈克·彭斯在美国加利福尼亚州西米谷罗纳德·里根总统图书馆举行的 2024 年美国总统竞选第二场共和党候选人辩论开始时合影2023 年 2 月 27 日。路透社/David Swanson;
;

;周三，七名共和党人在本党 2024 年第二次总统初选辩论中登台，旨在说服选民;他们可能是领先者唐纳德·特朗普的可行替代方案;，后者缺席了此次活动。

;

;以下是加利福尼亚州西米谷有时不守规矩的辩论的要点：

;

;在连续第二场辩论中，佛罗里达州州长罗恩·德桑蒂斯 (Ron DeSantis) 表现得冷静、稳定，这可能对破坏了他的候选资格。

;

;但他可能想开始担心尼基·哈利;向他的路线屈服;。

;

;德桑蒂斯的候选资格长期以来一直以他将成为党内特朗普的最佳替代者为前提。随着他在民意调查中的下滑，他创造了一个机会，黑利看起来最有可能抓住这个机会。

;

;与第一场辩论类似，前南卡罗来纳州州长黑利在周三表现得干脆利落、掌控全局。在早期对经济的讨论中，她可能是唯一一位概述了她将如何帮助中产阶级的候选人。

;

;后来，黑莉就医疗保健、教育和与民众的关系等问题给出了激进但微妙的答案。中国。她还表现出了与竞争对手斗争的意愿，包括德桑蒂斯、生物技术企业家维维克·拉马斯瓦米和美国参议员蒂姆·斯科特。

;

;当南卡罗来纳州同胞斯科特指责她在美国驻美国大使期间购买昂贵的窗帘时，联合国秘书长海莉（Haley 否认这样做）转向他说：“把它拿来，蒂姆。”德桑蒂斯试图在争吵中插话：“我是这里唯一一个被抓到的人。”参加了大规模的战斗，为佛罗里达州人民带来了巨大的胜利。”

;

;人群鼓掌。但德桑蒂斯是否做了足够的努力让他保持在第二位还有待观察。

;

;在上个月的第一场辩论中，38 岁的拉马斯瓦米表现出好斗而华丽的表现，提高了他在一些民意调查中的排名。< /p>;

;周三晚上，他的对手们准备将他击败一两下，但他们的倒刺最终给了他巨大的关注，并帮助他统治了比赛。

;

;在有一次，斯科特因为拉马斯瓦米之前在中国做生意而追究了他的责任。当拉马斯瓦米试图为自己辩护，称他已将自己的商业企业撤出中国时，黑利已准备好发起进攻。 “是的，就在你竞选总统之前，”她说。

;

;黑莉再次对他进行了攻击，因为他决定成为第一个加入中国短视频应用 TikTok 的共和党候选人。拉马斯瓦米将这一举动描述为一种帮助他接触年轻选民的方式；黑莉称其“令人愤怒”。

;

;“TikTok 是我们可能拥有的最危险的社交媒体资产之一，”她告诉他，并补充道“我们不能相信你。”

;

;拉马斯瓦米不但没有被这些攻击吓倒，反而充分利用了这些攻击。他在整个两个小时的对决中融入了谈话，成功地占据了宝贵的播出时间。

;< p>;德桑蒂斯花了超过 15 分钟的时间在辩论中发言，但当他发言时，他以一种前所未有的方式向前总统唐纳德·特朗普发难。

;

;他说正在发言的特朗普周三在底特律的;一群汽车工人;，而不是加入这场辩论本应该和他的竞争对手一起上台。

;

;“唐纳德·特朗普在行动中失踪了。他今晚应该上台，”德桑蒂斯说。“他有责任捍卫他的记录，他们增加了 7.8 万亿美元的债务。这为我们现在的通货膨胀奠定了基础。”

;

;当台上的所有其他竞争者都提出有关经济的问题时，德桑蒂斯耐心地等待着时机。对于一位迫切需要扭转颓势的候选人来说，这并不是一个理想的开始。

;

;最新的路透社/益普索 (Ipsos) 民意调查显示，他落后特朗普近 40 个百分点。在新罕布什尔州等一些提前投票的州，他面临着落入中间位置并被黑利 (Haley) 等竞争对手超越的危险。

;

; 45 岁的德桑蒂斯最终是否会从与党内最受欢迎的人物较量中受益还有待观察，但他对 77 岁的特朗普的好斗是他的一些支持者和捐助者几个月来一直希望看到的。

;

;当被问及美国南部边境的非法移民流动情况时，两位候选人试图通过展示他们的政策有多强硬来超越对方。

;

;这清楚地反映了非法移民和边境安全的影响是共和党初选选民最关心的问题之一。

;

;前新泽西州州长克里斯·克里斯蒂表示，他将在“第一天”就派遣国民警卫队前往美墨边境。

;

;Haley承诺在边境增加 25,000 个边境巡逻和移民执法工作岗位，将寻求庇护者留在墨西哥，并立即驱逐非法入境的被捕移民。

;

;为了不被抢风头，拉马斯瓦米走得更远。他承诺对所有非法入境的移民及其子女进行普遍驱逐，将南部边境完全军事化，并终止在美国境内非法出生的移民子女的出生公民权。

;

;“如果墨西哥外交官的孩子不享有与生俱来的公民身份，那么违法来到这里的非法移民的孩子也不能享受出生公民权，”拉马斯瓦米说。

;

;研究总统辩论的专家表示，很难创造一个选民会记住或会在社交媒体上疯传的时刻。他们通常会被认为是不真实的。

;

;但舞台上的共和党人仍然尝试过。

;

;前副总统迈克·彭斯非常渴望使用他的俏皮话，他决定参考之前的一段话关于美国汽车工人联合会罢工的问题，而不是他被问到的问题。

;

;“乔·拜登不属于纠察线。他属于失业线。”彭斯开玩笑说，然后停下来听人群中从未传来的欢呼声。

;

;后来，在讨论教育政策时，他指出自己“和老师睡了 38 年” ”。 （剧透：这是他的妻子凯伦·彭斯。）

;

;克里斯蒂本人尝试用一点幽默来抨击特朗普跳过辩论。面对镜头，克里斯蒂采取了直接与前总统交谈的姿势。

;

;“你今晚不在这里，因为你害怕站在这个舞台上捍卫你的记录。你在回避这些事情，”克里斯蒂说，他用手指着挑战。 “让我告诉你，如果你继续这样做会发生什么。这里没有人会再叫你唐纳德·特朗普了。我们要叫你唐老鸭。”

;

;观众中有一些叫喊声，但更多的是抱怨声，可能是因为大部分人群，比如共和党，都是由喜欢特朗普的选民组成的。克里斯蒂的竞选活动试图通过将其发布在曾经被称为 Twitter 的社交媒体网站 X 上来使其病毒式传播。一位评论者指出，“我们已经达到了新的畏缩程度。”

;

;在岛上投票

;

;辩论结束时，主持人达纳·佩里诺 (Dana Perino) 告诉候选人，如果有人有希望击败特朗普获得共和党提名，他们中的一些人将需要退出竞选。

;

;“这今晚舞台上的你们中的一个人应该被投票赶出这个岛吗？”她说，要求他们写下台上应该被淘汰的候选人的名字。

;

;所有竞争者都拒绝回答，德桑蒂斯称这是一个不尊重的问题。

;<克里斯蒂是台上最强烈反特朗普的候选人，她说：“我现在会投票支持唐纳德·特朗普离开这个岛。他需要退出这个过程。”

; Thu, 28 Sep 2023 12:55:03 +0800 Partial US government shutdown just four days away as congressional standoff continueshttps://reuters.com/article/usa-shutdown/house-senate-standoff-raises-chances-of-us-government-shutdown-idUSKBN30X0MK
;;2023-09-28T04:38:34Z;
;

;美国众议院议长凯文·麦卡锡 (Kevin McCarthy) 周三拒绝了参议院推进的一项权宜之计的拨款法案，使华盛顿更接近其< a href="/world/us/us-government-shutdown-what-c​​loses-what-stays-open-2023-09-21/">;美国政府十年来第四次部分关闭;，仅四次

;

;这将导致数十万联邦工作人员休假，并暂停从经济数据发布到营养福利等广泛的政府服务，直到国会设法通过一项拨款民主党总统乔·拜登将签署成为法律的法案。

;

;周二，参议院的计划以两党的广泛优势取得进展，将为政府提供资金到 11 月 17 日，从而使立法者有更多时间达成一致关于从 10 月 1 日开始的整个财政年度的资金水平。

;

;参议院民主党领袖查克·舒默 (Chuck Schumer) 表示，参议院将于周四对其法案进行下一次程序性投票，除非参议员们能够达成协议，允许他们尽快投票。

;

;麦卡锡的众议院正集中精力努力就 12 项单独的全年拨款法案中的更多法案达成一致，目前他们已经通过了其中一项。

;

;麦卡锡说，“我没有看到众议院支持”参议院的计划，尽管该法案得到了包括少数党领袖米奇·麦康奈尔在内的参议院共和党人的支持。

;

;众议院预计将投票深夜就具体拨款法案的修正案进行讨论，尽管即使所有四项法案都在周六之前签署成为法律，它们本身也不足以阻止政府部分关闭。

;

;几周前，拜登敦促国会通过短期延长 2023 财年支出，并提供紧急援助，以帮助州和地方政府应对自然灾害，并帮助乌克兰对抗俄罗斯。他还寻求新的边境安全资金。

;

;“如果我们政府关闭，从癌症研究到食品安全，许多重要的工作以及科学和健康可能会受到影响，”拜登周三表示。 “因此，美国人民需要众议院的共和党朋友做好他们的工作：为政府提供资金。”

;

;这场僵局已开始引起评级机构的关注，穆迪和惠誉均发出警告。可能会损害联邦政府的信誉。

;

;众议院共和党人希望制定更严格的立法，以阻止美国南部与墨西哥边境的移民流动，并比 6 月份实施更大幅度的支出削减。

;

;对政府关门的担忧已经在华盛顿以外蔓延。据当地媒体报道，在亚特兰大，吉米·卡特总统图书馆和博物馆将原定于周日庆祝前总统 99 岁生日的庆祝活动提前至周六，然后联邦资金可能会在午夜冻结。

;

;行政分支机构已经准备确定哪些联邦工作人员将继续留在工作岗位（在政府获得资助之前没有工资）以及哪些人将暂时休假。类似的演习也在国会进行，那里雇用了数千名立法助理和其他支持人员。

;

;“麦卡锡议长，摆脱政府关闭的唯一途径是两党合作，”舒默说。在向参议院发表的演讲中。

;

;参议院少数党领袖米奇·麦康奈尔表示，他反对政府关门。

;

;在政府关门期间，“边境巡逻队和 ICE 机构必须继续无偿工作”这位共和党议员周三对记者说，他指的是美国移民和海关执法局（ICE）。麦康奈尔补充说，解决方案“在政府关闭时比在政府开放时更有可能出现。”

;

;麦卡锡面临着;来自本党强硬派成员的威胁;，他们拒绝了拜登5月份与拜登谈判达成的1.59万亿美元可自由支配支出协议2024 财年预算案并于 6 月获得批准，要求再削减 1200 亿美元。

;

;一些强硬派还威胁说，如果麦卡锡通过一项需要民主党投票才能通过的支出法案，他们将罢免麦卡锡的领导职务。通过。

;

;麦卡锡表示，众议院共和党人可能会在周五将自己的权宜措施提交会议。

;

;目前尚不清楚众议院是否会投票通过该措施。< /p>;

;这场僵局是在华盛顿考虑拖欠该国超过 31 万亿美元的债务四个月后发生的，此举将震动全球金融市场。

;

;

;Donald Trump's Republican rivals clashed at a chaotic presidential debate on Wednesday, leveling attacks at the absent former president, Democratic President Joe Biden and one another over issues from China to immigration to the economy.

;

;But as the debate ended, no candidate appeared to have secured the sort of breakout moment that would alter the dynamics of a primary contest that Trump has dominated for months, despite his four criminal indictments.

;

;Trump, who led his nearest rival for the nomination by 37 percentage points in the ;most recent Reuters/Ipsos poll;, skipped the debate, as he did the first one in Wisconsin last month.

;

;Florida Governor Ron DeSantis called Trump "missing in action" and blamed him for adding trillions of dollars to the national debt.

;

;"He should be on this stage tonight," DeSantis said, drawing applause from the audience at the Ronald Reagan presidential library in Simi Valley, California. "He owes it to you to defend his record."

;

;The dig from DeSantis, whose poll numbers have declined after he had been widely seen as the leading Trump alternative, suggested he was more willing to attack the frontrunner after months of largely avoiding direct confrontation.

;

;Former New Jersey Governor Chris Christie, a frequent Trump critic, chimed in, saying Trump was "afraid" and mocking him as "Donald Duck" for skipping the debate.

;

;Mike Pence, vice president under Trump from 2017-2021, said he would take an opposite approach to Trump if elected. He said Trump planned to centralize power in the federal government but he would give more power to the states.

;

;Biden, the presumptive Democratic nominee for the November 2024 election, was also a frequent target for the Republican candidates, who castigated his handling of the economy and the southern border with Mexico.

;

;As in the first debate in August, entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy - a political neophyte whose campaign for the Republican presidential nomination is his first run for public office - repeatedly drew the ire of his fellow Republicans.

;

;"Every time, I hear you, I feel a little dumber," Nikki Haley, the former United Nations ambassador, told Ramaswamy after he defended joining TikTok, the Chinese-owned social media site that has raised security concerns among US officials. Ramaswamy said he uses the app to connect with young voters.

;

;All of the candidates vowed to take a muscular approach to immigration and attacked the Biden administration for failing to stem the migrant crisis that has fueled record illegal crossings at the southern border.

;

;The seven candidates are vying with Trump to become their party's nominee to face Biden in the 2024 election.

;

;Minutes before the debate kicked off, Trump ;delivered a speech; to autoworkers in the battleground state of Michigan, inserting ;himself into a national dispute; between striking workers and the country's leading automakers a day after Biden joined a union picket line.

;

;"They're all job candidates," Trump said dismissively of the seven Republicans at the debate. "Does anybody see any VP in the group? I don't think so."

;

;By shunning both debates, the former president signaled he was focused on Biden, his once and perhaps future opponent, rather than the Republican contenders who trail badly in the polls.

;

;With less than four months until Iowa's first-in-the-nation Republican nominating contest, Trump's rivals are running short on time to weaken his commanding hold on the primary campaign.

;

;Wednesday's debate loomed particularly large for DeSantis, whose campaign has already endured two staff shakeups as donors expressed concern about his inability to gain on Trump.

;

;DeSantis, 45, made his name nationally by opposing many US government policies to prevent the spread of COVID-19. He has since become a leading figure fighting what he argues are overly progressive policies favored by educators and corporations.

;

;Haley, meanwhile, was hoping a second consecutive strong debate performance will ;convince some Republican donors; she has the best odds of unseating Trump.

;

;North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum also qualified for the debate.

;

;Immigration took center stage during the debate.

;

;DeSantis promised to deploy the US military against Mexican cartels, while entrepreneur Vivek Ramaswamy said he would try to revoke birthright citizenship for the children of those who entered the country illegally.

;

;Even when asked about the expanding US autoworkers' strike, Senator Tim Scott turned the subject to the border while criticizing Biden for joining the picket line on Tuesday.

;

;"Biden should not be on the picket line," Scott said. "He should be on the southern border working to close our southern border because it is unsafe, wide open and insecure, leading to the deaths of 70,000 Americans in the last 12 months because of fentanyl."

;

;Most of the candidates expressed support for continued aid to Ukraine, though DeSantis said he would not offer a "blank check." Ramaswamy warned that backing Ukraine was pushing Russia further toward China, prompting renewed criticisms from his rivals that he would appease Russian President Vladimir Putin.

;

;The moderators did not ask the candidates about Trump's ;myriad legal problems;. The 77-year-old businessman-turned-politician has been indicted in four criminal cases, and on Tuesday, a New York state judge found that he committed fraud by inflating the value of his business assets.

;The United States is backing a new undersea internet cable connecting several Pacific islands, according to a plan for the project seen by Reuters, boosting Washington's interests in a region where it is vying for influence with China.

;

;The Central Pacific Cable would connect American Samoa with Guam - two US territories - and extend to up to 12 more Pacific islands, according to a document showing the cable route. Guam is home to a key US military base.

;

;Details of the cable were displayed at an industry conference in Singapore by the developers, Paul McCann and John Hibbard, two veteran subsea cable consultants. APTelecom, a US-based telecoms consultancy, is carrying out the feasibility study. APTelecom, Hibbard and McCann declined to comment.

;

;The new cable could connect the US territories with Papua New Guinea, Samoa, Tuvalu, Fiji, Nauru, Marshall Islands, Kiribati, Cook Islands, Wallis and Futuna and the Federated States of Micronesia, the plan showed.

;

;Further funding for the project would most likely come from multilateral donors such as the World Bank and aid agencies in the United States, Australia, New Zealand, the plan said.

;

;Undersea internet cables typically take at least 3-5 years to be developed and installed. The proposed cable would stretch thousands of kilometres.

;

;A ;White House fact sheet; released on Monday after ;a meeting; between Pacific Island leaders and President Joe Biden in Washington ;confirmed; the US Trade and Development Agency would fund a $3 million feasibility study for the cable. The statement didn't state the countries involved.

;

;This would be the first undersea cable connecting Tuvalu, a tiny nation of about 11,000 people, the USTDA said in a post on its Facebook page.

;

;Undersea fibre-optic cables, which criss-cross the ocean floor and transmit 99% of transcontinental internet traffic, have become a key arena of competition between the US and China, as reported in ;a Reuters investigation; in March.

;

;The Pacific islands, which form a vast arc to the north of US ally Australia, are strategically important for US naval movements and are home to valuable minerals and fisheries.

;

;Island nations in the Pacific have vulnerable internet infrastructure. ;Tonga was cut off; from global telecommunication networks for a month last year after a volcanic eruption and tsunami severed its only undersea cable.

;

;Last year, the Biden administration pledged to help Pacific islanders fend off China's attempts at "economic coercion". Beijing signed a security agreement with the Solomon Islands last year, prompting fears of a militarization of the region.

;

;Washington intervened two years ago to block a Chinese company from building another subsea internet cable in the Pacific islands, ;Reuters reported at the time;.

;

;The United States, Australia and Japan this year ;agreed to pay for; and revive that project, known as the East Micronesia Cable. It will connect the Island nations of Nauru, Kiribati and Micronesia.

;The seven Republicans on stage at their party's second 2024 presidential primary debate aimed on Wednesday to convince voters ;they could be a viable alternative; to frontrunner Donald Trump, who skipped the event.

;

;Here are takeaways from the debate in Simi Valley, California:

;

;It took more than 15 minutes for Florida Governor Ron DeSantis to speak, but when he did, he unloaded on former President Trump in a way he has not before.

;

;He said Trump, who was speaking to a ;crowd of autoworkers; in Detroit on Wednesday instead of joining the debate, should have been on the stage with his primary rivals.

;

;"Donald Trump is missing an action. He should be on the stage tonight," DeSantis said. “He owes it to you to defend his record where they added 7.8 trillion to the debt. That set the stage for the inflation that we have now.”

;

;DeSantis had patiently bided his time as all the other contenders on stage took questions on the economy. It was not an ideal start for a candidate who desperately needs to reverse his fading fortunes.

;

;The most recent Reuters/Ipsos poll had him falling almost 40 percentage points behind Trump. In some early-voting states such as New Hampshire, he is in danger of dropping into the middle of the pack.

;

;Whether DeSantis, 45, ultimately will benefit from taking on the most popular figure in the party remains to be seen, but his combativeness toward Trump, 77, was something some of his supporters and donors have wanted to see for months.

;

;Asked about the flow of illegal immigration across America's southern border, the candidates tried to outdo one another by showing how hardline their policies would be.

;

;It was a clear reflection of how illegal immigration and border security are among the top concerns for Republican primary voters.

;

;Former New Jersey Governor Chris Christie said he would send the National Guard to the US-Mexico border “on Day One."

;

;Nikki Haley, former UN ambassador and South Carolina governor, promised to create an additional 25,000 Border Patrol and immigration enforcement jobs at the border, keep asylum seekers in Mexico and immediately deport captured immigrants who enter illegally.

;

;Not to be upstaged, biotech investor Vivek Ramaswamy went even further. He pledged universal deportation for all immigrants who enter illegally and their children, the complete militarization of the southern border and the end of birthright citizenship for the children of immigrants who enter illegally born on US soil.

;

;"If the kid of a Mexican diplomat doesn't enjoy birthright citizenship, then neither does the kid of an illegal migrant who broke the law to come here," Ramaswamy said.

;

;Experts who have studied presidential debates will tell you: It's hard to manufacture a moment that voters will remember or that will go viral on social media. They typically come off as inauthentic.

;

;But that doesn't mean the Republicans on stage didn't try.

;

;Former Vice President Mike Pence was so eager to use his one-liner, he decided to refer to an earlier question about the United Auto Workers strike rather than one he was asked.

;

;“Joe Biden doesn't belong on the picket line. He belongs on the unemployment line,” Pence joked before pausing for a roar from the crowd that never came.

;

;Later, when discussing education policy, he noted that he has “been sleeping with a teacher for 38 years.” (Spoiler: It's his wife, Karen Pence.)

;

;That didn't stop Christie from trying a little humor himself in blasting Trump for skipping the debate. Addressing the camera, Christie adopted the pose of speaking to the former president directly.

;

;“You're not here tonight because you're afraid of being on this stage and defending your record. You're ducking these things,” Christie said, his finger pointed in challenge. “And let me tell you what's going to happen if you keep doing that. No one up here is going to call you Donald Trump anymore. We're gonna call you Donald Duck."

;

;There were some hoots but more moans from the audience, likely because much of the crowd, like the Republican Party, was comprised of voters who like Trump. Christie's campaign tried to make it viral by posting it on X, the social media site once known as Twitter. One commenter noted, “We've reached new levels of cringe.”
